content: Place yourself in the other person's shoes. It's easy to get lost in yourself and to only consider the impact of the other person's "telling" on you. But active listening is blocked by your inward thinking. Instead, you must open out and look at the problems from the other person's perspective: and assume that if you had been in their shoes, you would have come to the same conclusion, and not seen your way through the problem any faster than them. [1] By being a good listener this can also help you become better friends with the person by getting to know more about them. Remember that you have two ears and one mouth for a reason. This means that you should be listening more than you are talking. It is more beneficial to listen than it is to talk. When listening to people, engage in the conversation and make eye contact so they know that you care about what they are saying (even if you don't care, it is still polite). People who listen more are more observant and therefore more thoughtful and have a better understanding of things. Make sure you really are listening and not doing something else. Try to make sure you are completely focused on the person who is talking and not get sidetracked. Make sure you are making eye contact with the person, not someone else or something else. Instead of immediately judging the person who is speaking, or coming up with a "solution" right away, just take the time to listen and to look at the situation from the other person's perspective. [2] Think about how you would feel if someone was silently judging you. This will help you truly hear the person instead of forming your own opinions before you truly understand the situation at hand. Avoid comparing the person's experiences to your own. Though you may think that the best thing you can do to really listen is to compare the person's experiences to your own, this is far from the truth. If the person is talking about dealing with a death in the family, you can share some wisdom, but avoid saying, "That's exactly like how it was with me..." This can come off as offensive or insensitive especially when you compare something really serious to your own less-intense experiences, such as comparing the person's divorce to your three-month long relationship this may cause discomfort to the person talking. You may think that this is the best way to be helpful and to approach the situation, but this type of thinking is actually reductive and can make the person feel like you're not really listening at all. Avoid saying "I" or "me" a lot. This is a good indicator that you're focusing more on yourself than on the person's situation. [3] Of course, if the person knows that you've had a similar experience, then he or she may actively ask for your opinion. In this case, you can offer it, but be cautious about acting like your experiences are exactly like the other person's. This might seem as though you are just trying to make fake situations to seem helpful. Don't try to help immediately. Some people think that, when they're listening, they should also have their gears turning to find a quick and easy solution to the person's problem. Instead of this attitude, you should take what the person says at face value, and take the time to think of a "solution" when the person is speaking — and only if he or she is really looking for help in this way. If you start frantically thinking of all of the quick fixes for the person's problems, then you won't really be listening. Focus on absorbing everything the person is saying to you. Only after that can you really try to help. Limit distractions. We live in a society that is filled with so many distractions. We are constantly listening to so much noise that it’s a challenge to truly listen to another person. In order for you to be a good listener, you need to limit distractions during your conversation, whether it be the television, telephones or interruptions. It takes a mental decision to limit distractions when you are listening to someone else. Sympathize. Show them that you care by nodding at appropriate times so they know that you are listening. Also says little things such as "Yeah" when the person is talking about something that they want you to agree on (you can tell by their tone of voice) or "Wow" when the person talks about a tragedy or something bad done against them. Saying these words shows them that you are not only listening but also paying attention. Say these words at the appropriate times and softly so that you don't come off as overbearing and interrupting. Try to appeal to your sensitive side and comfort the person if in distress. But on the other hand most people do not want to be pitied. So comfort them but don't make yourself seem higher than them. [4] Remember what you've been told. One important part of being a good listener is to actually absorb the information the person has told you. So, if the person is telling you about his problems with his best friend, Jake, and you've never met the guy before, you can at least remember his name so you can refer to him that way, making it seem like you're better acquainted with the situation. If you don't remember any names, details, or important events, then it won't sound like you're listening. It's okay if you don't have a razor sharp memory. However, if you keep having to stop and ask for clarification or keep forgetting who everyone is, then yeah, you won't come off as a very good listener. You don't have to remember every little detail, but you don't want the person who is speaking to feel like they have to repeat themselves a million times, either. Follow up. Another important part of being a good listener is that you go beyond just hearing the person out having a conversation, and never thinking about it again. If you really want to show that you care, then you should ask the person about the situation the next time you're alone together, or even shoot him or her a text or give a phone call to see how the situation is progressing. If it's something serious like an impending divorce, a job search, or even a health complication, then it can be very nice to show that you care by checking in, even when you're not being asked to. Don't be put off however if they don't want to follow up, accept their decision but tell them you're always there to support them. The person who talked to you might be touched that you made the effort to actually think about him or her beyond your conversation and to even check in to see how he or she is caring. This takes your listening skills to the next level. Of course, there's a difference between following up and nagging the person. If the person talked to you about how she wants to quit her job, you probably don't want to send a text every day asking if she did it yet, or you'll be putting unneeded pressure on the situation and creating stress instead of helping. Know what not to do. Knowing what to avoid when you're trying to be a good listener can be almost as helpful as knowing what to do. If you want the speaker to take you seriously and to think that you are being respectful, then here are some general things to avoid: Don't interrupt in the middle of a point. Don't interrogate the person. Instead, gently ask questions when it's . Don't try to change the subject, even if it's a little uncomfortable. Avoid saying, "It's not the end of the world" or "You'll feel better in the morning." This just minimizes the person's problems and makes him or her feel bad. Make eye contact with the person so that they realize that you are interested and are listening. Be silent at first. It might sound obvious and trite, but one of the biggest obstacles to listening is resisting the urge to voice impulsive thoughts. Likewise, many people falsely express empathy by sharing similar their own experiences. Both "gut" responses can be helpful, but they are usually overused and, ultimately, abused. Put aside your own needs, and wait patiently for the other person to unfold their thoughts at their own pace and in their own way. Reassure the person of your confidentiality. If the person is telling you something pretty private or important, then you should make it clear that you're a trustworthy person who can keep their mouth shut. Say that the person can trust you, that whatever is said stays between you two, and that your word is your bond. If the person is unsure of whether or not you can really be trusted, then he or she will be less likely to open up. Also don't force anyone to open up to you as this makes them uncomfortable or angry. Of course, when you say that what the person says will remain confidential, it should be true, unless there are circumstances that prevent you from keeping it to yourself, such as if the person is suicidal and you're deeply concerned. If you can't actually be trusted in general, though, then you'll never be a good listener. Be encouraging when you do speak. It's important to use empathetic sounding back at appropriate intervals during the conversation so the speaker doesn't feel like you're not listening at all. It's helpful to "summarize and restate" or "repeat and encourage" the main points. This will help the conversation feel fluid and will make the speaker less self-conscious about talking. Here's what you should do: Repeat and encourage: Repeat some things the speaker said and, at the same time, provide positive feedback as encouragement. For example, you might say, "I can see that you didn't enjoy having to take the blame. I wouldn't have either." Go easy with this technique, though. Use the empathetic sound back as a nudge from time-to-time because if you overwork it, you will come across as patronizing. [5] Summarize and restate: It is highly useful to summarize your understanding of what the "teller" has said and to restate it in your own words. This reassures the speaker that you have truly been listening to what he or she is saying and that you "got it". It also provides the speaker with an opportunity to correct mistaken assumptions and misconceptions on your part. Make sure to leave the door wide open with statements like, "I may be wrong, but..." or "...Correct me if I am wrong." This technique is especially useful when you find yourself getting frustrated or you sense that your listening focus is wavering. Ask meaningful and empowering questions. Refrain from probing or putting the other person on the defensive. Rather, aim to use questions as a means by which the speaker can begin to reach his or her own conclusions about the issues being raised. This can help the speaker make his or her own conclusions without sounding judgmental or too forceful. Here are some things to keep in mind: Once you have shown empathetic listening, it is time to move into empowered listening: Re-frame the questions you ask. For example, "You didn't enjoy having to take the blame. But I cannot understand why you feel blamed rather than merely being asked not to do something that way." Wording the question in this manner presents the speaker with a need to respond directly to your lack of grasping something. In the response process, the speaker should begin to move from a more emotional response to a more logical and constructive response. Wait for the person to open up. In the process of encouraging a constructive response, an active listener must be ever-so-patient and let the speaker acquire his or her full flow of thoughts, feelings and ideas. These may, at first, start as a trickle and the full flow may take a long time to develop. If you press too early and ask too many personal, probing questions, that may actually have the opposite of the intended effect and may make the person feel defensive and reluctant to share any information. Keep your patience and keep your place in the "teller's" shoes. It sometimes helps to imagine why the "teller" has worked into such a situation. [6] Do not interrupt with what you feel or think about the "telling". Instead, wait for the other person to ask your opinion before breaking the flow of their discourse. Active listening requires the listener to shelve his or her own opinions temporarily and patiently await appropriate breaks in conversation. When the conversation breaks, provide a summary or an empathetic concurrence. If you interrupt the person too soon, then he or she will be frustrated and won't fully absorb what you're saying. The person will be eager to finish saying his or her part and you'll be causing a nuisance and a distraction. Abstain from giving direct advice (unless you're asked for it). Instead, let the individual talk the situation out and find his or her own way. This empowers both the individual and you. It is the course most likely to result in beneficial change and self-understanding for the "teller" and for you. Reassure the speaker. Whatever the conclusion of the conversation, let the speaker know that you have been happy to listen and to be a sounding board. Make it clear that you are open to further discussion if need be, but that you will not pressure him or her at all. In addition, reassure the speaker of your intention to keep the discussion confidential. Even if the speaker is in a terrible situation and saying something like, "It's all going to be okay" seems completely inappropriate, you can still reassure the speaker by saying that you're there to listen and to help. You can even pat the speaker's hand or knee, put an arm around him or her, or give another reassuring touch. Do whatever is appropriate to the situation. You don't want to overstep your bounds when it comes to touching. Offer to assist with any solutions if you have the ability, time and expertise. Do not build up false hopes , though. If the only resource you can provide is to continue to be an active listener, make that very clear. This, in and of itself, this is an extremely valuable help. When giving advice remember to make it neutral and not too influenced by your own experiences. Think about what is best for the person in question rather than what you did although this may help. Make eye contact. Eye contact is important when you are listening. If you give your friend the impression you aren't interested and are distracted, they may never open up to you again. When it comes to being a good listener, it’s important for you to have eye contact with the other person. When someone is talking to you, focus directly on their eyes so that they will know with certainty that you are absorbing every single word. Even if the topic is not interesting to you, at least respect and truly listen to what the speaker has to say. Don't stare off in space. [7] Focus your eyes, ears and your thoughts only on him/her and become a good listener. Don't concentrate on thinking about what you will say next, but instead, focus fully on what the other person is saying. (Remember that it's about the person, not you.) Give the speaker your full attention. If you want to be a good listener, then it's important for you to create a conducive physical and mental space. Remove all distractions and confer all of your attention to the person who has something to say to you. Turn off communication devices (including cell phones) and arrange to talk in a place with no distractions. Once you are face-to-face, quiet your mind and pay attention to what the other person is telling.Show them that you are helpful. Pick a place that is free of distractions or other people who might grab your attention. If you go to a coffee shop, make sure you're focused on the person who is speaking, not the interesting characters who walk in and out of the door. If you're talking in a public place like a restaurant or a cafe, avoid sitting near a television that's on. Even if you're determined to give the person all of your attention, it can be tempting to take a quick look at the television, especially if your favorite team is playing. Encourage the speaker with body language. Nodding your head will indicate that you understand what the speaker is saying, and will encourage them to continue. Adopting body postures, positions and movements that are similar to the speaker (mirroring) will enable the speaker to relax and open up more. Try looking straight into their eyes. Not only does this show you are listening, but it shows you take real interest in what they are saying. Another way to have encouraging body language is to turn your body toward the speaker. If you're turned away from the speaker, then it may look like you're itching to leave. If you cross your legs, for example, cross your leg toward the speaker instead of away. Don't cross your arms over your chest, either. This will make you appear standoffish or skeptical even if you don't actually feel that way. Listen actively to express your interest. Active listening involves the entire body and face — both yours and that of the speaker. You can be quiet while still making it clear that you are hanging on to every word that the speaker is telling you. Here's how you can make the most of the situation by being an active listener: Your words : Though you don't have to say, "Mmhmm," "I see," or "Right," every five seconds or it will begin to get annoying, you can throw in an encouraging phrase here and there to show that you're paying attention.If that person whom you are talking to really means something to you,then you will surely pay attention and help them sort out their problem if there is any. Your expression : Look interested and meet the gaze of the speaker from time to time. Do not overwhelm the speaker by staring intently, but do reflect friendliness and openness to what you are listening to. Read between the lines : Always be alert for things that have been left unsaid and for cues that can help you gauge the speaker's true feelings. Watch the facial and body expressions of the "teller" to try to gather all information you can, not just from the words. Imagine what kind of state of mind would have made you acquire such expressions, body language and volume. Speak at approximately the same energy level as the other person. This way, they will know that the message is getting through and that there is no need to repeat. Don't expect them to open up immediately. Be patient and willing to just listen, without giving any advice. Try to repeat what the other person is saying to confirm the exact meaning. Sometimes words can mean two different things. The best way to confirm and avoid misunderstanding between the conversationalists is to repeat what the other person is saying so that the other person knows you were listening and both of you have the same idea. Consider their circumstances. If they are a sensitive person, don't give them "tough love."

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Be-a-Good-Listener">How to Be a Good Listener</a></h1>
<div class="" id="expert_coauthor">
<a class="author_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Author Info</a><span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a class="expert_coauthor_link ss_review" href="#article_info_section">Reader-Approved</a>
</div>

This article has over 1,366,314 views, and 24 testimonials from our readers, earning it our reader-approved status.
		<a class="sp_learn_more_link" href="/wikiHow:About-wikiHow#Why_should_you_choose_wikiHow_first.3F_sub">Learn more...</a>
</div>
</div>
<p>Being a good listener can help you to see the world through the eyes of others. It enriches your understanding and expands your capacity for empathy. It also increases your contact with the outside world by helping you improve your <a href="/Develop-Good-Communication-Skills" title="Develop Good Communication Skills">communication skills</a>. Good listening skills can provide you with a deeper level of understanding about someone’s situation, and helps to know what words are best to use or which words to avoid. As simple as listening (and acknowledging) may seem, doing it well, particularly when disagreements arise, takes sincere effort and lots of practice. If you want to know how to be a good listener, read on to get started!</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Listening_with_an_Open_Mind_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Listening_with_an_Open_Mind">Listening with an Open Mind</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-1-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-1-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-1-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_1c139c17f7" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1c139c17f7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-1-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Place yourself in the other person's shoes.</b> It's easy to get lost in yourself and to only consider the impact of the other person's "telling" on you. But active listening is blocked by your inward thinking. Instead, you must open out and look at the problems from the other person's perspective: and assume that if you had been in their shoes, you would have come to the same conclusion, and not seen your way through the problem any faster than them.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> By being a good listener this can also help you become better friends with the person by getting to know more about them.

<ul>
<li>Remember that you have two ears and one mouth for a reason. This means that you should be listening more than you are talking. It is more beneficial to listen than it is to talk. When listening to people, engage in the conversation and make eye contact so they know that you care about what they are saying (even if you don't care, it is still polite). People who listen more are more observant and therefore more thoughtful and have a better understanding of things. Make sure you really are listening and not doing something else. Try to make sure you are completely focused on the person who is talking and not get sidetracked. Make sure you are making eye contact with the person, not someone else or something else.</li>
<li>Instead of immediately judging the person who is speaking, or coming up with a "solution" right away, just take the time to listen and to look at the situation from the other person's perspective.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> Think about how you would feel if someone was silently judging you. This will help you truly hear the person instead of forming your own opinions before you truly understand the situation at hand.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-2-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-2-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_5ae6109684" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5ae6109684')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid comparing the person's experiences to your own.</b> Though you may think that the best thing you can do to really listen is to compare the person's experiences to your own, this is far from the truth. If the person is talking about dealing with a death in the family, you can share some wisdom, but avoid saying, "That's exactly like how it was with me..." This can come off as offensive or insensitive especially when you compare something really serious to your own less-intense experiences, such as comparing the person's divorce to your three-month long relationship this may cause discomfort to the person talking.

<ul>
<li>You may think that this is the best way to be helpful and to approach the situation, but this type of thinking is actually reductive and can make the person feel like you're not really listening at all.</li>
<li>Avoid saying "I" or "me" a lot. This is a good indicator that you're focusing more on yourself than on the person's situation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Of course, if the person knows that you've had a similar experience, then he or she may actively ask for your opinion. In this case, you can offer it, but be cautious about acting like your experiences are exactly like the other person's. This might seem as though you are just trying to make fake situations to seem helpful.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-3-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-3-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-3-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-3-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_da4fde3938" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_da4fde3938')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-3-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-3-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't try to help immediately.</b> Some people think that, when they're listening, they should also have their gears turning to find a quick and easy solution to the person's problem. Instead of this attitude, you should take what the person says at face value, and take the time to think of a "solution" when the person is speaking — and only if he or she is really looking for help in this way. If you start frantically thinking of all of the quick fixes for the person's problems, then you won't really be listening.

<ul>
<li>Focus on absorbing everything the person is saying to you. Only after that can you really try to help.</li>
<li>Limit distractions. We live in a society that is filled with so many distractions. We are constantly listening to so much noise that it’s a challenge to truly listen to another person. In order for you to be a good listener, you need to limit distractions during your conversation, whether it be the television, telephones or interruptions. It takes a mental decision to limit distractions when you are listening to someone else.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-4-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-4-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e4/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-4-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_c2f7631fa9" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c2f7631fa9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e4/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-4-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Sympathize.</b> Show them that you care by nodding at appropriate times so they know that you are listening. Also says little things such as "Yeah" when the person is talking about something that they want you to agree on (you can tell by their tone of voice) or "Wow" when the person talks about a tragedy or something bad done against them. Saying these words shows them that you are not only listening but also paying attention. Say these words at the appropriate times and softly so that you don't come off as overbearing and interrupting. Try to appeal to your sensitive side and comfort the person if in distress. But on the other hand most people do not want to be pitied. So comfort them but don't make yourself seem higher than them.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-5-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-5-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_c7022ba87e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c7022ba87e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remember what you've been told.</b> One important part of being a good listener is to actually absorb the information the person has told you. So, if the person is telling you about his problems with his best friend, Jake, and you've never met the guy before, you can at least remember his name so you can refer to him that way, making it seem like you're better acquainted with the situation. If you don't remember any names, details, or important events, then it won't sound like you're listening.

<ul>
<li>It's okay if you don't have a razor sharp memory. However, if you keep having to stop and ask for clarification or keep forgetting who everyone is, then yeah, you won't come off as a very good listener. You don't have to remember every little detail, but you don't want the person who is speaking to feel like they have to repeat themselves a million times, either.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_cef0f7569d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_cef0f7569d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Follow up.</b> Another important part of being a good listener is that you go beyond just hearing the person out having a conversation, and never thinking about it again. If you really want to show that you care, then you should ask the person about the situation the next time you're alone together, or even shoot him or her a text or give a phone call to see how the situation is progressing. If it's something serious like an impending divorce, a job search, or even a health complication, then it can be very nice to show that you care by checking in, even when you're not being asked to. Don't be put off however if they don't want to follow up, accept their decision but tell them you're always there to support them.

<ul>
<li>The person who talked to you might be touched that you made the effort to actually think about him or her beyond your conversation and to even check in to see how he or she is caring. This takes your listening skills to the next level.</li>
<li>Of course, there's a difference between following up and nagging the person. If the person talked to you about how she wants to quit her job, you probably don't want to send a text every day asking if she did it yet, or you'll be putting unneeded pressure on the situation and creating stress instead of helping.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_8c7d2a586a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8c7d2a586a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know what not to do.</b> Knowing what to avoid when you're trying to be a good listener can be almost as helpful as knowing what to do. If you want the speaker to take you seriously and to think that you are being respectful, then here are some general things to avoid:

<ul>
<li>Don't interrupt in the middle of a point.</li>
<li>Don't interrogate the person. Instead, gently ask questions when it's needed(i.e.between gaps or lulls when the person is not talking).</li>
<li>Don't try to change the subject, even if it's a little uncomfortable.</li>
<li>Avoid saying, "It's not the end of the world" or "You'll feel better in the morning." This just minimizes the person's problems and makes him or her feel bad. Make eye contact with the person so that they realize that you are interested and are listening.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Knowing_What_to_Say_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Knowing_What_to_Say">Knowing What to Say</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_37dd955212" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_37dd955212')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be silent at first.</b> It might sound obvious and trite, but one of the biggest obstacles to listening is resisting the urge to voice impulsive thoughts. Likewise, many people falsely express empathy by sharing similar their own experiences. Both "gut" responses can be helpful, but they are usually overused and, ultimately, abused.

<ul>
<li>Put aside your own needs, and <i>wait patiently</i> for the other person to unfold their thoughts at their own pace and in their own way.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-9-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-9-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-9-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-9-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_67b26f630c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_67b26f630c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-9-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-9-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reassure the person of your confidentiality.</b> If the person is telling you something pretty private or important, then you should make it clear that you're a trustworthy person who can keep their mouth shut. Say that the person can trust you, that whatever is said stays between you two, and that your word is your bond. If the person is unsure of whether or not you can really be trusted, then he or she will be less likely to open up. Also don't force anyone to open up to you as this makes them uncomfortable or angry.

<ul>
<li>Of course, when you say that what the person says will remain confidential, it should be true, unless there are circumstances that prevent you from keeping it to yourself, such as if the person is suicidal and you're deeply concerned. If you can't actually be trusted in general, though, then you'll never be a good listener.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-10-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-10-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-10-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-10-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_54eee6c0a6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_54eee6c0a6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-10-Version-4.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-10-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be encouraging when you <i>do</i> speak.</b> It's important to use empathetic sounding back at appropriate intervals during the conversation so the speaker doesn't feel like you're not listening at all. It's helpful to "summarize and restate" or "repeat and encourage" the main points. This will help the conversation feel fluid and will make the speaker less self-conscious about talking. Here's what you should do:

<ul>
<li>
<i>Repeat and encourage:</i> Repeat some things the speaker said and, at the same time, provide positive feedback as encouragement. For example, you might say, "I can see that you didn't enjoy having to take the blame. I wouldn't have either." Go easy with this technique, though. Use the empathetic sound back as a nudge from time-to-time because if you overwork it, you will come across as patronizing.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>
<i>Summarize and restate:</i> It is highly useful to summarize your understanding of what the "teller" has said and to restate it in your own words. This reassures the speaker that you have truly been listening to what he or she is saying and that you "got it". It also provides the speaker with an opportunity to correct mistaken assumptions and misconceptions on your part.</li>
<li>Make sure to leave the door wide open with statements like, "I may be wrong, but..." or "...Correct me if I am wrong." This technique is especially useful when you find yourself getting frustrated or you sense that your listening focus is wavering.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-11-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-11-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-11-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_db306d3421" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_db306d3421')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-11-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask meaningful and empowering questions.</b> Refrain from probing or putting the other person on the defensive. Rather, aim to use questions as a means by which the speaker can begin to reach his or her own conclusions about the issues being raised. This can help the speaker make his or her own conclusions without sounding judgmental or too forceful. Here are some things to keep in mind:

<ul>
<li>Once you have shown empathetic listening, it is time to move into empowered listening: Re-frame the questions you ask. For example, "You didn't enjoy having to take the blame. But I cannot understand why you feel blamed rather than merely being asked not to do something that way."</li>
<li>Wording the question in this manner presents the speaker with a need to respond directly to <i>your</i> lack of grasping something. In the response process, the speaker should begin to move from a more emotional response to a more logical and constructive response.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-12-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-12-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-12-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_8f54d311cc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8f54d311cc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-12-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wait for the person to open up.</b> In the process of encouraging a constructive response, an active listener must be ever-so-patient and let the speaker acquire his or her full flow of thoughts, feelings and ideas. These may, at first, start as a trickle and the full flow may take a long time to develop. If you press too early and ask too many personal, probing questions, that may actually have the opposite of the intended effect and may make the person feel defensive and reluctant to share any information.

<ul>
<li>Keep your patience and keep your place in the "teller's" shoes. It sometimes helps to imagine why the "teller" has worked into such a situation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-13-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-13-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_1f1d836d0e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1f1d836d0e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do not interrupt with what you feel or think about the "telling".</b> Instead, wait for the other person to ask your opinion before breaking the flow of their discourse. Active listening requires the listener to shelve his or her own opinions temporarily and patiently await appropriate breaks in conversation. When the conversation breaks, provide a summary or an empathetic concurrence.

<ul>
<li>If you interrupt the person too soon, then he or she will be frustrated and won't fully absorb what you're saying. The person will be eager to finish saying his or her part and you'll be causing a nuisance and a distraction.</li>
<li>Abstain from giving direct advice (unless you're asked for it). Instead, let the individual talk the situation out and find his or her own way. This empowers both the individual and you. It is the course most likely to result in beneficial change and self-understanding for the "teller" and for you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-14-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-14-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-14-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_f0cb7013ce" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f0cb7013ce')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-14-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reassure the speaker.</b> Whatever the conclusion of the conversation, let the speaker know that you have been happy to listen and to be a sounding board. Make it clear that you are open to further discussion if need be, but that you will not pressure him or her at all. In addition, reassure the speaker of your intention to keep the discussion confidential. Even if the speaker is in a terrible situation and saying something like, "It's all going to be okay" seems completely inappropriate, you can still reassure the speaker by saying that you're there to listen and to help.

<ul>
<li>You can even pat the speaker's hand or knee, put an arm around him or her, or give another reassuring touch. Do whatever is appropriate to the situation. You don't want to overstep your bounds when it comes to touching.</li>
<li>Offer to assist with any solutions if you have the ability, time and expertise. <i>Do not build up false hopes</i>, though. If the only resource you can provide is to continue to be an active listener, make that very clear. This, in and of itself, this is an extremely valuable help.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-15-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-15-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-15-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_f688f73c50" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f688f73c50')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-15-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 8" class="step_num">8</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_8"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">When giving advice remember to make it neutral and not too influenced by your own experiences.</b> Think about what is best for the person in question rather than what you did although this may help.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Appropriate_Body_Language_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Appropriate_Body_Language">Using Appropriate Body Language</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-16-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-16-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-16-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_a237e7ac83" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a237e7ac83')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-16-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make eye contact.</b> Eye contact is important when you are listening. If you give your friend the impression you aren't interested and are distracted, they may never open up to you again. When it comes to being a good listener, it’s important for you to have eye contact with the other person. When someone is talking to you, focus directly on their eyes so that they will know with certainty that you are absorbing every single word. Even if the topic is not interesting to you, at least respect and truly listen to what the speaker has to say. Don't stare off in space.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Focus your eyes, ears and your thoughts only on him/her and become a good listener. Don't concentrate on thinking about what you will say next, but instead, focus fully on what the other person is saying. (Remember that it's about the person, not you.)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-17-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-17-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-17-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_c62c5390df" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c62c5390df')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-17-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give the speaker your full attention.</b> If you want to be a good listener, then it's important for you to create a conducive physical and mental space. Remove all distractions and confer all of your attention to the person who has something to say to you. Turn off communication devices (including cell phones) and arrange to talk in a place with no distractions. Once you are face-to-face, quiet your mind and pay attention to what the other person is telling.Show them that you are helpful.

<ul>
<li>Pick a place that is free of distractions or other people who might grab your attention. If you go to a coffee shop, make sure you're focused on the person who is speaking, not the interesting characters who walk in and out of the door.</li>
<li>If you're talking in a public place like a restaurant or a cafe, avoid sitting near a television that's on. Even if you're determined to give the person all of your attention, it can be tempting to take a quick look at the television, especially if your favorite team is playing.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-18-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-18-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-18-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-18-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_5e8141f6c6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5e8141f6c6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-18-Version-3.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-18-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Encourage the speaker with body language.</b> Nodding your head will indicate that you understand what the speaker is saying, and will encourage them to continue. Adopting body postures, positions and movements that are similar to the speaker (mirroring) will enable the speaker to relax and open up more. Try looking straight into their eyes. Not only does this show you are listening, but it shows you take real interest in what they are saying.

<ul>
<li>Another way to have encouraging body language is to turn your body toward the speaker. If you're turned away from the speaker, then it may look like you're itching to leave. If you cross your legs, for example, cross your leg toward the speaker instead of away.</li>
<li>Don't cross your arms over your chest, either. This will make you appear standoffish or skeptical even if you don't actually feel that way.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-19-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-19-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-19-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_fd2774dca1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fd2774dca1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-19-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Listen actively to express your interest.</b> Active listening involves the entire body and face — both yours and that of the speaker. You can be quiet while still making it clear that you are hanging on to every word that the speaker is telling you. Here's how you can make the most of the situation by being an active listener:

<ul>
<li>
<i>Your words</i>: Though you don't have to say, "Mmhmm," "I see," or "Right," every five seconds or it will begin to get annoying, you can throw in an encouraging phrase here and there to show that you're paying attention.If that person whom you are talking to really means something to you,then you will surely pay attention and help them sort out their problem if there is any.</li>
<li>
<i>Your expression</i>: Look interested and meet the gaze of the speaker from time to time. Do not overwhelm the speaker by staring intently, but do reflect friendliness and openness to what you are listening to.</li>
<li>
<i>Read between the lines</i>: Always be alert for things that have been left unsaid and for cues that can help you gauge the speaker's true feelings. Watch the facial and body expressions of the "teller" to try to gather all information you can, not just from the words. Imagine what kind of state of mind would have made you acquire such expressions, body language and volume.</li>
<li>
<i>Speak at approximately the same energy level as the other person.</i> This way, they will know that the message is getting through and that there is no need to repeat.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-20-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=61428" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-20-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-20-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0aa3d3ab8d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0aa3d3ab8d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Listener Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid61428-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Listener-Step-20-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't expect them to open up immediately.</b> Be patient and willing to just listen, without giving any advice.

<ul>
<li>Try to repeat what the other person is saying to confirm the exact meaning. Sometimes words can mean two different things. The best way to confirm and avoid misunderstanding between the conversationalists is to repeat what the other person is saying so that the other person knows you were listening and both of you have the same idea.</li>
<li>Consider their circumstances. If they are a sensitive person, don't give them "tough love."</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Listening_Tips_sub"></a><div class="section steps sample sticky">
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Listening_Tips">Listening Tips</span></h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<div id="sd_container">
<div class="sd_thumb"><a href="/Sample/Listening-Tips"><img class="whcdn" data-src="/images/thumb/2/2e/Listening-Tips.png/340px-Listening-Tips.png" height="440" id="5cc524d63348c" name="5cc524d63348c" src="https://www.wikihow.com" width="340"/><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('5cc524d63348c')
//]]>
</script><noscript>
<p class="lone_p"><img class="whcdn" height="440" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Listening-Tips.png/340px-Listening-Tips.png" width="340"/></p>
</noscript>
<span>Listening Tips</span></a></div>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="61428" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="23957" data-caid="24830" data-cqid="23974" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="191032" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="54">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What does it mean to place yourself in someone else's shoes?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">It means imagining how the other person feels. It could also mean viewing the situation from the other person's point of view. For example, you may laugh at a blond joke, but your blond friend may find that same joke to be very offensive. If you "place yourself in your friend's shoes," you might see why your friend feels targeted and insulted.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>5</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>54</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="33080" data-caid="33953" data-cqid="33097" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="376068" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="8" data-votes_up="54">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if someone keeps talking about something I don't know about?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Admit that you don't know about it and then do some research after the conversation. Look it up on the internet or ask around. Don't pretend to know something you don't, because the person may find out later and decide not to trust you in the future.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>8</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>54</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="14729" data-caid="15595" data-cqid="14739" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="140556" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="12" data-votes_up="62">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if the person talking is really boring?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Good question. Have you ever listened to your boss talk about his boring golf game? Or, have you ever listened to a small child talk incoherently about his day? One reason for listening is to give the speaker the pleasure of speaking. It’s not about your interests. Besides, would it be okay for people to ignore you every time they found you boring? It’s all about the golden rule and give and take.
There are things you can do, however, to make things more interesting. You can ask questions about the context or history. “How did you get into sock puppets?” “What’s your favorite sock puppet and why?” You might learn something about the other person. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>12</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>62</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="130642" data-caid="131515" data-cqid="130659" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="336496" data-submitter_id="3887452" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="8" data-votes_up="39">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What are the qualities of a good listener?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/6/62/3887452.jpg?20161103163159)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:T-Bag">T Bag</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">This quote from Stephen R. Covey is a pretty good guideline to follow:

 “Most people do not listen with the intent to understand; they listen with the intent to reply.”

</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>8</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>39</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="151954" data-caid="152827" data-cqid="151971" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="821203" data-submitter_id="2558198" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="19">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What are the qualities of being a good listener?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/8/84/2558198.jpg?20180906044243)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Susan-Chacko">Susan Chacko</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">A good listener must be able to recall information they heard, understand the broader context and not just details, be attentive to non-verbal cues, and be empathetic.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>5</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>19</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="121233" data-caid="122106" data-cqid="121250" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="644676" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="20">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I deal with the urge to talk while listening?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Sometimes writing something down can help. I do this in class so I can still process my thoughts while giving others a chance to speak. Just jot a quick note to remind yourself what you wanted to say and keep listening.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>7</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>20</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="151955" data-caid="152828" data-cqid="151972" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="899871" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="16">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if I feel wrong about what the person has said?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can state your own opinion, but you must do it respectfully. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>7</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>16</span></a>
</div>

</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="128243" data-caid="129116" data-cqid="128260" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="737716" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="15">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I was at a church function with my sick wife. I struck up a conversation with someone, but I struggled to be a good listener because my mind was also on how my wife was doing and a passerby tried to initiate another conversation. How should I handle a situation like this in the future?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Try to maintain contact with your wife, maybe with an arm around her as you're paying attention to the speaker. If a passerby tries to initiate another conversation, just smile and hold up a finger as if to say "Just a minute," then resume paying attention to the speaker. After the conversation, smile at your wife and ask, "You good?" to let her know that you are concerned about her well-being. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>7</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>15</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
